etymologies: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin contractio(n-), from contrahere ‘draw together’ (see contract)

examples.text: the general contraction of the industry did further damage to morale

definitions: the process in which a muscle becomes or is made shorter and tighter

examples.text: neurons control the contraction of muscles
repeat the exercise, holding each contraction for one second

shortDefinitions: process in which muscle becomes or is made shorter and tighter

definitions: a shortening of the uterine muscles occurring at intervals before and during childbirth

examples.text: she was now in no doubt that she was having contractions

shortDefinitions: shortening of uterine muscles occurring at intervals before and during childbirth

definitions: the process of shortening a word by combination or elision.
shortDefinitions: process of shortening word by combination or elision

definitions: a word or group of words resulting from shortening an original form

examples.text: “goodbye” is a contraction of “God be with you.”

shortDefinitions: word or group of words resulting from shortening original form
